elements.content: Three new CoII–azido complexes, [Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n (1), [Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ·nH2O (2), and [Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ·2nMeOH (3) [o-BDC = 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate, m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, p-BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and L = di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane], have been constructed from di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane, azido, and different aromatic dicarboxylates under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 takes a dia topology with the Co3 units as connecting nodes, and complex 2 is a two-dimensional sql layer that further extends to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network via π···π interaction between m-BDC ligands, while complex 3 forms a 3D pcu network based on Co2 units as nodes. The investigaton of magnetic properties of complexes 1–3 demonstrates that they all display ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions but antiferromagnetic interaction between Co3 or Co2 units.
elements.clean_text: Three new CoII-azido complexes, [Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n  (1), [Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ⋅nH2O (2), and [Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ⋅2nMeOH (3) [o-BDC = 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate, m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, p-BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, and L = di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane], have been constructed from di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane, azido, and different aromatic dicarboxylates under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 takes a dia topology with the Co3 units as connecting nodes, and complex 2 is a two-dimensional sql layer that further extends to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network via π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between m-BDC ligands, while complex 3 forms a 3D pcu network based on Co2 units as nodes. The investigaton of magnetic properties of complexes 1-3 demonstrates that they all display ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions but antiferromagnetic interaction between Co3 or Co2 units.

elements.content: Three new CoII−azido complexes, [Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n (1), [Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ·nH2O (2), and [Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ·2nMeOH (3) [H2-o-BDC = 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2-m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2-p-BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, L = di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane], constructed from different dicarboxylate-like ligands have been obtain by a semirigid di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane ligand as the third ligand under hydrothermal conditions. The studies of the magnetic properties of complexes 1−3 demonstrate that all of them display ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions but antiferromagnetic interaction between Co3 or Co2 units.
elements.clean_text: Three new CoII-azido complexes, [Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n  (1), [Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ⋅nH2O (2), and [Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ⋅2nMeOH (3) [H2-o-BDC = 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2-m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2-p-BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, L = di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane], constructed from different dicarboxylate-like ligands have been obtain by a semirigid di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane ligand as the third ligand under hydrothermal conditions. The studies of the magnetic properties of complexes 1-3 demonstrate that all of them display ferromagnetic coupling between CoII ions but antiferromagnetic interaction between Co3 or Co2 units.

elements.content: In the past two decades, molecule-based magnetic materials have become a hot research topic. The rational design of new molecular magnets relies mainly on two basic aspects: spin carriers and bridges. For the former, attention is commonly focused on the magnetic 3d transition metals such as Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu. For the latter, the short bridging ligands that can effectively mediate the magnetic coupling play a key role in the synthesis of magnetic materials. As a versatile ligand, azido was widely used in the construction of effective magnetic systems. In particular, because of its various possible binding modes, zero-dimensional (0D) (discrete), one-dimensional (1D) (chain), two-dimensional (2D) (sheet), and three-dimensional (3D) (network) coordination polymers have been observed. For magnetic exchange of azido, the end-on (EO) binding mode generally shows ferromagnetic (FM) coupling and the end-to-end (EE) mode generally shows antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling. Furthermore, the magnetic coupling also depends on the detailed coordination geometries, such as the M–Nazido–M angles and the dihedral angle between the M–N–N–N and N–N–N–M′ mean planes. As a bridging ligand, an important feature of azido is that it can be further utilized to cooperate with the ancillary bridging ligand to construct magnetic metal coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past two decades, molecule-based magnetic materials have become a hot research topic. The rational design of new molecular magnets relies mainly on two basic aspects: spin carriers and bridges. For the former, attention is commonly focused on the magnetic 3d transition metals such as Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu. For the latter, the short bridging ligands that can effectively mediate the magnetic coupling play a key role in the synthesis of magnetic materials. As a versatile ligand, azido was widely used in the construction of effective magnetic systems. In particular, because of its various possible binding modes, zero-dimensional (0D) (discrete), one-dimensional (1D) (chain), two-dimensional (2D) (sheet), and three-dimensional (3D) (network) coordination polymers have been observed. For magnetic exchange of azido, the end-on (EO) binding mode generally shows ferromagnetic (FM) coupling and the end-to-end (EE) mode generally shows antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling. Furthermore, the magnetic coupling also depends on the detailed coordination geometries, such as the M-Nazido-M angles and the dihedral angle between the M-N-N-N and N-N-N-M' mean planes. As a bridging ligand, an important feature of azido is that it can be further utilized to cooperate with the ancillary bridging ligand to construct magnetic metal coordination polymers.

elements.content: Until now, we have synthesized many metal–azido complexes containing ancillary bridging ligand(s) such as nicotinate/isonicotinate with interesting magnetic behaviors. A recent trend is the employment of three or more ligands in the reaction system. The loss of a degree of synthetic control is more than offset by the vast diversity of structural types using a combination of ligands. In view of this consideration, we assume that the nicotinate/isonicotinate can be divided into ditopic groups, that is, the N atom of pyridine and the carboxylate group, which can be substituted with a N-containing heterocyclic ligand (such as neutral pyridinyl or azolyl) and an aromatic carboxylate ligand, respectively (Scheme ). That is to say, the general aromatic carboxylate/azido/azolyl (ArCOO–/N3 –/N) ligand combination is used in metal–azido chemistry.
elements.clean_text: Until now, we have synthesized many metal-azido complexes containing ancillary bridging ligand(s) such as nicotinate/isonicotinate with interesting magnetic behaviors. A recent trend is the employment of three or more ligands in the reaction system. The loss of a degree of synthetic control is more than offset by the vast diversity of structural types using a combination of ligands. In view of this consideration, we assume that the nicotinate/isonicotinate can be divided into ditopic groups, that is, the N atom of pyridine and the carboxylate group, which can be substituted with a N-containing heterocyclic ligand (such as neutral pyridinyl or azolyl) and an aromatic carboxylate ligand, respectively (Scheme ). That is to say, the general aromatic carboxylate/azido/azolyl (ArCOO-/N3 -/N) ligand combination is used in metal-azido chemistry.

elements.clean_text: 1  Di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane and Aromatic Dicarboxylic Acids

elements.content: As part of our continuing interest and efforts in developing new azido systems, we have fortunately obtained three new CoII–azido complexes, including one neutral ligand and two kinds of negative ligands. In this work, by the use of the rigid aromatic dicarboxylate-like ligands, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-o-BDC), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-m-BDC), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-p-BDC), together with azido and di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane (L), we successfully obtained three new CoII–azido coordination polymers, [Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n (1), [Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ·nH2O (2), and [Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ·2nMeOH (3), which have been well characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectra, powder X-ray diffraction, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structures, topological analysis, and magnetic properties of these complexes have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: As part of our continuing interest and efforts in developing new azido systems, we have fortunately obtained three new CoII-azido complexes, including one neutral ligand and two kinds of negative ligands. In this work, by the use of the rigid aromatic dicarboxylate-like ligands, 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-o-BDC), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-m-BDC), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-p-BDC), together with azido and di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane (L), we successfully obtained three new CoII-azido coordination polymers, [Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n  (1), [Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ⋅nH2O (2), and [Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ⋅2nMeOH (3), which have been well characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectra, powder X-ray diffraction, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal structures, topological analysis, and magnetic properties of these complexes have also been investigated.

elements.content:
All starting materials were commercially available and used as received. L was synthesized according to the reference method.

Elemental analysis of C, H, and N was conducted with a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV and 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Simulation of the XRPD spectra was conducted by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury (Hg) program available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Remarks

All starting materials were commercially available and used as received. L was synthesized according to the reference method. 

Elemental analysis of C, H, and N was conducted with a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV and 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Simulation of the XRPD spectra was conducted by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury (Hg) program available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org.

elements.content: The magnetic measurements were taken on a Quantum Design MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer. Susceptibility measurements were taken in a field of 1000 Oe, and magnetization measurements were taken at 2 K. All data were corrected for diamagnetism estimated from Pascal’s constants, and an experimental correction for the sample holder was applied.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic measurements were taken on a Quantum Design MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer. Susceptibility measurements were taken in a field of 1000 Oe, and magnetization measurements were taken at 2 K. All data were corrected for diamagnetism estimated from Pascal's constants, and an experimental correction for the sample holder was applied.

elements.content:
Caution! Azido–metal complexes are potentially explosive; only a small amount of material should be prepared with care.

Synthesis

Single crystals of 1–3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by the method described below for 1, except H2-m-BDC for 2 and H2-p-BDC for 3 were used as ligands instead of H2-o-BDC.

[Co<sub>3</sub>(L)<sub>2</sub>(<italic toggle="yes">o</italic>-BDC)<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

1 was hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. A mixture of CoSO4·7H2O (1.5 mmol), L (0.5 mmol), H2-o-BDC (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), and CH3OH (15 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 24 h. Pink crystals were collected in ∼10% yield based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H24Co3N14O8: C, 40.70; H, 2.73; N, 22.15. Found: C, 40.96; H, 2.87; N, 22.07. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3413, 3122, 2077, 1561, 1401, 1233, 1085, 771, 719, 613 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Caution! Azido-metal complexes are potentially explosive; only a small amount of material should be prepared with care. 

Synthesis

Single crystals of 1-3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by the method described below for 1, except H2-m-BDC for 2 and H2-p-BDC for 3 were used as ligands instead of H2-o-BDC.

[Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n  (1)

 1 was hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. A mixture of CoSO4⋅7H2O (1.5 mmol), L (0.5 mmol), H2-o-BDC (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), and CH3OH (15 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 24 h. Pink crystals were collected in ~10% yield based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H24Co3N14O8: C, 40.70; H, 2.73; N, 22.15. Found: C, 40.96; H, 2.87; N, 22.07. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3413, 3122, 2077, 1561, 1401, 1233, 1085, 771, 719, 613 cm-1.

elements.content: Purple crystals. Yield: ∼15% based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H26Co3N14O9: C, 39.88; H, 2.90; N, 21.71. Found: C, 39.47; H, 2.73; N, 20.91. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3415, 3122, 2082, 1611, 1561, 1397, 1095, 717 cm–1.

[Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ⋅nH2O (2)

Purple crystals. Yield: ~15% based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H26Co3N14O9: C, 39.88; H, 2.90; N, 21.71. Found: C, 39.47; H, 2.73; N, 20.91. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3415, 3122, 2082, 1611, 1561, 1397, 1095, 717 cm-1.

[Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ⋅2nMeOH (3)

Light purple crystals. Yield: ~15% based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C24H28Co2N14O6: C, 39.68; H, 3.88; N, 26.99. Found: C, 39.88; H, 3.72; N, 26.87. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3414, 3134, 2066, 1617, 1555, 1400, 1234, 1083, 1027, 942, 842, 747, 615 cm-1.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1–3 were collected on a Scx-Mini diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were determined by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS). The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Detailed crystallographic data are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Determinations

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1-3 were collected on a Scx-Mini diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were determined by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined with SHELXL (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS). The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Detailed crystallographic data are summarized in Table .

wR = {∑[w(F o 2 – F c 2)2]/∑w(F o 2)2}1/2.

Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. In the lattice, there are two crystallographically independent CoII ions: Co1 and Co2. The asymmetric unit of this complex consists of one Co1 ion, half a Co2 ion, one azido anion, one L ligand, and one o-BDC ligand. The Co1 ion is located in an octahedral coordination environment, and its coordination sphere consists of four O atoms from two o-BDC anions and two N atoms from one azido anion and one L ligand. The Co1–N/O distances are in the normal range of 2.075–2.232 Å (see Table S1 of the ). Co2 ion lies in a slightly distorted octahedral coordination sphere that is comprised of two O atoms from two o-BDC anions, two N atoms from two azido anions, and two N atoms from two L ligands (Co2–O1, 2.132 Å; Co2–N1, 2.172 Å; Co2–N4, 2.125 Å). The azido anions take μ-1,1 mode linking two CoII ions. The distances of the CoII ions bridged by the azido anion are 3.255 Å (Co1···Co2). The carboxylate group bridges three CoII ions with the O1 atom taking the μ2 mode (Co1–O1–Co2, 96.46°) and the O2 atom taking the μ1 mode (Figure a). The 3D structure can be described as follows. First, the azido anion takes the μ-1,1 mode (with a Co1–N4–Co2 angle of 98.29°) together with the carboxylate groups linking two types but three CoII ions forming a Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit (Figure b), which is further built into a 1D chain by double syn–anti carboxylato bridges. Then these CoII chains are connected via L ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

[Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n  (1)

Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. In the lattice, there are two crystallographically independent CoII ions: Co1 and Co2. The asymmetric unit of this complex consists of one Co1 ion, half a Co2 ion, one azido anion, one L ligand, and one o-BDC ligand. The Co1 ion is located in an octahedral coordination environment, and its coordination sphere consists of four O atoms from two o-BDC anions and two N atoms from one azido anion and one L ligand. The Co1-N/O distances are in the normal range of 2.075-2.232 Å (see Table S1 of the ). Co2 ion lies in a slightly distorted octahedral coordination sphere that is comprised of two O atoms from two o-BDC anions, two N atoms from two azido anions, and two N atoms from two L ligands (Co2-O1, 2.132 Å; Co2-N1, 2.172 Å; Co2-N4, 2.125 Å). The azido anions take μ-1,1 mode linking two CoII ions. The distances of the CoII ions bridged by the azido anion are 3.255 Å (Co1⋅⋅⋅Co2). The carboxylate group bridges three CoII ions with the O1 atom taking the μ2 mode (Co1-O1-Co2, 96.46°) and the O2 atom taking the μ1 mode (Figure a). The 3D structure can be described as follows. First, the azido anion takes the μ-1,1 mode (with a Co1-N4-Co2 angle of 98.29°) together with the carboxylate groups linking two types but three CoII ions forming a Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit (Figure b), which is further built into a 1D chain by double syn-anti carboxylato bridges. Then these CoII chains are connected via L ligands to form a 3D framework (Figure c).

elements.content: The framework structure of 1 may be simplified by the application of a topological approach. Each Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit is connected to four other different Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units through four L ligands and four o-BDC anions and can be viewed as a four-connection node (Figure b). Thus, on the basis of the topology analysis conducted with TOPOS version 4.0, structure 1 can be simplified as a four-connection uninodal 3D 66 (dia) topology (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: The framework structure of 1 may be simplified by the application of a topological approach. Each Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit is connected to four other different Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units through four L ligands and four o-BDC anions and can be viewed as a four-connection node (Figure b). Thus, on the basis of the topology analysis conducted with TOPOS version 4.0, structure 1 can be simplified as a four-connection uninodal 3D 66 (dia) topology (Figure d).

elements.content: (a) Linkage and coordination modes of the ligands and CoII ions in 1. (b) Linkage modes between Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units. Pink atoms denote the Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit. (c) 3D structure of complex 1. (d) Topology net of complex 1. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Linkage and coordination modes of the ligands and CoII ions in 1. (b) Linkage modes between Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units. Pink atoms denote the Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit. (c) 3D structure of complex 1. (d) Topology net of complex 1. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity.

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. There are two crystallographically independent CoII ions in the lattice: Co1 and Co2. There is half a Co1 ion, one Co2 ion, one azido anion, one L ligand, one m-BDC ligand, and one water molecule in the asymmetric unit of complex 2. The Co1 ion is located at an inversion center with an octahedral coordination environment in which the equatorial plane consists of four N atoms from two azido anions and two L ligands, and the axial sites are occupied by two O atoms from two m-BDC ligands. The Co1 ion has two pairs of Co1–N distances of 2.145 and 2.133 Å, and the Co1–O distance is 2.076 Å (see Table S1 of the ). The Co2 ion adopts pentacoordinate geometry, being coordinated by three O atoms (Co2–O1, 1.994 Å; Co2–O3B, 2.416 Å; Co2–O4B, 2.010 Å) from two m-BDC ligands and two N atoms (Co2–N1, 2.001 Å; Co2–N7C, 2.033 Å) from one azido anion and one L ligand. The azido anion takes the μ-1,1 mode linking two CoII ions, with a Co–N–Co angle of 112.98°, and the distances of the CoII ions bridged by the azido anion are 3.458 Å (Co1···Co2) (Figure a). The 3D structure can be described as follows. The carboxylate groups from m-BDC ligands taking syn–syn mode bridge two CoII ions together with the azido anions forming a carboxylate/EO–azido mixed-bridged linear Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit (Figure b). Then these Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units are connected via L ligands and m-BDC anions forming a 2D network along the a–c plane (Figure c). Finally, these 2D planes form a 3D supramolecular network through the π···π interaction between m-BDC ligands (Figure S1 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
[Co3(L)2(m-BDC)2(N3)2] n ⋅nH2O (2)

Complex 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅. There are two crystallographically independent CoII ions in the lattice: Co1 and Co2. There is half a Co1 ion, one Co2 ion, one azido anion, one L ligand, one m-BDC ligand, and one water molecule in the asymmetric unit of complex 2. The Co1 ion is located at an inversion center with an octahedral coordination environment in which the equatorial plane consists of four N atoms from two azido anions and two L ligands, and the axial sites are occupied by two O atoms from two m-BDC ligands. The Co1 ion has two pairs of Co1-N distances of 2.145 and 2.133 Å, and the Co1-O distance is 2.076 Å (see Table S1 of the ). The Co2 ion adopts pentacoordinate geometry, being coordinated by three O atoms (Co2-O1, 1.994 Å; Co2-O3B, 2.416 Å; Co2-O4B, 2.010 Å) from two m-BDC ligands and two N atoms (Co2-N1, 2.001 Å; Co2-N7C, 2.033 Å) from one azido anion and one L ligand. The azido anion takes the μ-1,1 mode linking two CoII ions, with a Co-N-Co angle of 112.98°, and the distances of the CoII ions bridged by the azido anion are 3.458 Å (Co1⋅⋅⋅Co2) (Figure a). The 3D structure can be described as follows. The carboxylate groups from m-BDC ligands taking syn-syn mode bridge two CoII ions together with the azido anions forming a carboxylate/EO-azido mixed-bridged linear Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit (Figure b). Then these Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units are connected via L ligands and m-BDC anions forming a 2D network along the a-c plane (Figure c). Finally, these 2D planes form a 3D supramolecular network through the π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between m-BDC ligands (Figure S1 of the ).

elements.content: As described above, the trinuclear Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit is connected by four L ligands and four m-BDC anions and can be considered as a four-connection node (Figure b). If the bridging ligand can be considered as a linear linker, then the resulting topology of 2 is a four-connectiond uninodal 2D 44 (sql) network (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: As described above, the trinuclear Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit is connected by four L ligands and four m-BDC anions and can be considered as a four-connection node (Figure b). If the bridging ligand can be considered as a linear linker, then the resulting topology of 2 is a four-connectiond uninodal 2D 44 (sql) network (Figure d).

elements.content: (a) Linkage and coordination modes of the ligands and CoII ions in 2. (b) Link modes between Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units. Pink atoms denote the Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit. (c) 3D structure of complex 2. (d) Topology net of complex 2. The noncoordinated solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Linkage and coordination modes of the ligands and CoII ions in 2. (b) Link modes between Co3(COO)2(N3)2 units. Pink atoms denote the Co3(COO)2(N3)2 unit. (c) 3D structure of complex 2. (d) Topology net of complex 2. The noncoordinated solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity.

elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one CoII ion, one azido anion, one L ligand, half a p-BDC ligand, and one MeOH molecule. As shown in Figure a, Co1 is hexacoordinated by four N atoms from two L ligands (Co1–N1, 2.114 Å; Co1–N4C, 2.082 Å) and two azido anions (Co1–N5, 2.192 Å; Co1–N5A, 2.069 Å) and two O atoms from one p-BDC ligand (Co1–O1, 2.300 Å; Co1–O2, 2.144 Å) to complete a distorted octahedral geometry. Both the Co–N and Co–O bond distances fall into the range of normal value (see Table S1 of the ). The azido anion bridges the CoII ions in μ-1,1 mode with a Co–N–Co angle of 102.56° and a Co1···Co1A distance of 3.325 Å. Two azido anions bridge two CoII ions forming a Co2(N3)2 unit (Figure b). The Co2(N3)2 units are connected by L ligands and p-BDC ligands forming a 3D framework (Figure c).
elements.clean_text:
[Co2(L)2(p-BDC)(N3)2] n ⋅2nMeOH (3)

Complex 3 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one CoII ion, one azido anion, one L ligand, half a p-BDC ligand, and one MeOH molecule. As shown in Figure a, Co1 is hexacoordinated by four N atoms from two L ligands (Co1-N1, 2.114 Å; Co1-N4C, 2.082 Å) and two azido anions (Co1-N5, 2.192 Å; Co1-N5A, 2.069 Å) and two O atoms from one p-BDC ligand (Co1-O1, 2.300 Å; Co1-O2, 2.144 Å) to complete a distorted octahedral geometry. Both the Co-N and Co-O bond distances fall into the range of normal value (see Table S1 of the ). The azido anion bridges the CoII ions in μ-1,1 mode with a Co-N-Co angle of 102.56° and a Co1⋅⋅⋅Co1A distance of 3.325 Å. Two azido anions bridge two CoII ions forming a Co2(N3)2 unit (Figure b). The Co2(N3)2 units are connected by L ligands and p-BDC ligands forming a 3D framework (Figure c).

elements.content: To identify the topology of complex 3, considering the Co2(N3)2 unit as a six-connectiond node (Figure b), we can simplify the network as a six-connection uninodal 3D net with a Schläfli symbol of 412.63 (pcu) (Figure d).

(d) Topology net of complex 3. The noncoordinated solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity.

(c) 3D structure of complex 3. (d) Topology net of complex 3. The noncoordinated solvent molecules and hydrogen atoms have been omitted for the sake of clarity.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were taken on crystalline samples of complexes 1–3, whose phase purity was confirmed by XRPD (see Figure S2 of the ). The obtained data indicated FM coupling between CoII ions but AFM coupling between Co3 or Co2 units in 1–3.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Magnetic measurements were taken on crystalline samples of complexes 1-3, whose phase purity was confirmed by XRPD (see Figure S2 of the ). The obtained data indicated FM coupling between CoII ions but AFM coupling between Co3 or Co2 units in 1-3.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data of 1 were collected for the crushed crystalline sample in the 2–300 K temperature range (Figure a). The value of χm T at 300 K is 10.58 cm3 K mol–1, which is consistent with that of three CoII ions with strong spin–orbit coupling. As the temperature decreases, the χm T product increases to 46.07 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, indicating FM coupling between CoII ions in 1. The susceptibility of 1 follows the Curie–Weiss law of χm = C/(T – θ) at >80 K with a Curie constant C of 10.31 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant θ of 12.58 K indicating FM coupling in 1. The C value is consistent with that expected for three six-coordinated high-spin CoII ions (C = 2.8–3.4 cm3 K mol–1 for one high-spin CoII ion).
elements.clean_text: Magnetic susceptibility data of 1 were collected for the crushed crystalline sample in the 2-300 K temperature range (Figure a). The value of χm T at 300 K is 10.58 cm3 K mol-1, which is consistent with that of three CoII ions with strong spin-orbit coupling. As the temperature decreases, the χm T product increases to 46.07 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, indicating FM coupling between CoII ions in 1. The susceptibility of 1 follows the Curie-Weiss law of χm = C/(T - θ) at >80 K with a Curie constant C of 10.31 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant θ of 12.58 K indicating FM coupling in 1. The C value is consistent with that expected for three six-coordinated high-spin CoII ions (C = 2.8-3.4 cm3 K mol-1 for one high-spin CoII ion).

elements.content: χm T vs T plots of the complex (◼) at 1 kOe and 1/χm vs T plots of the complex (●). The red solid line is the best fit to the Curie–Weiss law for (a) 1, (b) 2, and (c) 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  χm T vs T plots of the complex (◼) at 1 kOe and 1/χm vs T plots of the complex (●). The red solid line is the best fit to the Curie-Weiss law for (a) 1, (b) 2, and (c) 3.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of χm T for complex 2 as a χm T versus T plot (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility for three CoII ions) in the range of 2–300 K, under an applied field of 1 kOe, is shown in Figure b. During cooling, the value of χm T continues to increase from 8.44 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K to 18.23 cm3 K mol–1 at 6 K. Below this temperature, because of the AFM interaction between Co3 units and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS), the χm T value decreases sharply to 15.56 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Fitting the data at 60–300 K with the Curie–Weiss law gives a C of 8.33 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of 13.83 K. The C value is consistent with the value of 8.44 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K. The positive value of θ indicates FM coupling between CoII ions.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of χm T for complex 2 as a χm T versus T plot (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility for three CoII ions) in the range of 2-300 K, under an applied field of 1 kOe, is shown in Figure b. During cooling, the value of χm T continues to increase from 8.44 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K to 18.23 cm3 K mol-1 at 6 K. Below this temperature, because of the AFM interaction between Co3 units and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS), the χm T value decreases sharply to 15.56 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. Fitting the data at 60-300 K with the Curie-Weiss law gives a C of 8.33 cm3 K mol-1 and a θ of 13.83 K. The C value is consistent with the value of 8.44 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K. The positive value of θ indicates FM coupling between CoII ions.

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data for complex 3 were collected with an applied dc field of 1 kOe in the 2–300 K temperature range (Figure c). The χm T product at 300 K equals 3.43 cm3 K mol–1, in agreement with that expected for one isolated CoII ion with spin–orbital coupling. As the temperature decreases, the χm T product increases slightly, indicating FM interactions within CoII ions, until a maximum value of 3.78 cm3 K mol–1 is reached at 50 K. Then because of the AFM interaction between Co2 units and/or ZFS, the χm T value decreases to 0.79 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Fitting of the χm –1–T data above 80 K using the Curie–Weiss law gives a C of 3.33 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of 9.36 K, which support the presence of FM interactions in the Co2 unit. The abnormal value at 40 K might be attributed to the presence of traces of paramagnetic impurities.
elements.clean_text: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data for complex 3 were collected with an applied dc field of 1 kOe in the 2-300 K temperature range (Figure c). The χm T product at 300 K equals 3.43 cm3 K mol-1, in agreement with that expected for one isolated CoII ion with spin-orbital coupling. As the temperature decreases, the χm T product increases slightly, indicating FM interactions within CoII ions, until a maximum value of 3.78 cm3 K mol-1 is reached at 50 K. Then because of the AFM interaction between Co2 units and/or ZFS, the χm T value decreases to 0.79 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. Fitting of the χm -1-T data above 80 K using the Curie-Weiss law gives a C of 3.33 cm3 K mol-1 and a θ of 9.36 K, which support the presence of FM interactions in the Co2 unit. The abnormal value at 40 K might be attributed to the presence of traces of paramagnetic impurities.

elements.content: At 2 K, the M versus H measurements of complexes 1–3 from 0 to 50 Oe are given in Figure . The M values increase quickly at low field and trend to saturation at high field with an M value of 7.49 Nβ for 1 and 7.58 Nβ for 2, which are smaller than the expected ferromagnetic coupling value of 9 Nβ for three CoII ions. Both of the slightly unsaturated values of M mol/Nβ at 50 kOe for 1 and 2 also confirm that the weak AFM interaction takes place in the magnetic systems. Thus, FM coupling between CoII ions is shown, but the weak AFM interaction between Co3 units takes place in 1 and 2. For 3, the M values increase laggardly at low field and sharply increase at high field but without saturation. At 50 kOe, complex 3 has an M value of 1.93 Nβ; this M value is far below the expected ferromagnetic coupling values of 6 Nβ for two CoII ions. It shows that there is an AFM interaction between Co2 units in 3.
elements.clean_text: At 2 K, the M versus H measurements of complexes 1-3 from 0 to 50 Oe are given in Figure . The M values increase quickly at low field and trend to saturation at high field with an M value of 7.49 Nβ for 1 and 7.58 Nβ for 2, which are smaller than the expected ferromagnetic coupling value of 9 Nβ for three CoII ions. Both of the slightly unsaturated values of M mol/Nβ at 50 kOe for 1 and 2 also confirm that the weak AFM interaction takes place in the magnetic systems. Thus, FM coupling between CoII ions is shown, but the weak AFM interaction between Co3 units takes place in 1 and 2. For 3, the M values increase laggardly at low field and sharply increase at high field but without saturation. At 50 kOe, complex 3 has an M value of 1.93 Nβ; this M value is far below the expected ferromagnetic coupling values of 6 Nβ for two CoII ions. It shows that there is an AFM interaction between Co2 units in 3.

elements.content: M vs H plots of complexes 1 and 2 at 2.0 K. The inset shows the M vs H plot of complex 3 at 2.0 K.
elements.clean_text: 5   M vs H plots of complexes 1 and 2 at 2.0 K. The inset shows the M vs H plot of complex 3 at 2.0 K.

elements.content: As discussed above, in complex 1, the Co–NEO–Co angle of 98.29° and the Co1–O1–Co2 angle of 96.46° are propitious to ferromagnetic exchange between the involved CoII centers. In complex 2, the bridge is a syn–syn carboxylate/EO–azido mixed bridge. In this situation, as Thompson et al. and Escuer et al. proposed, the countercomplementarity effect of the two bridges may explain the ferromagnetic coupling, not simply the sum of the two separated components. In complex 3, the ferromagnetic coupling may due to the double EO–azido (Co–NEO–Co, 102.56°) bridge.
elements.clean_text: As discussed above, in complex 1, the Co-NEO-Co angle of 98.29° and the Co1-O1-Co2 angle of 96.46° are propitious to ferromagnetic exchange between the involved CoII centers. In complex 2, the bridge is a syn-syn carboxylate/EO-azido mixed bridge. In this situation, as Thompson et al. and Escuer et al. proposed, the countercomplementarity effect of the two bridges may explain the ferromagnetic coupling, not simply the sum of the two separated components. In complex 3, the ferromagnetic coupling may due to the double EO-azido (Co-NEO-Co, 102.56°) bridge.

elements.content: Three new CoII–azido coordination complexes with a semiflexible di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane ligand and different dicarboxylate-like ligands as the subligands have been structurally and magnetically characterized. This work shows that it is feasible to substitute the N-containing carboxylate with a neutral N-containing heterocyclic ligand and dicarboxylate in the azido system, which have generated three novel 3D CoII–azido complexes from different dicarboxylate-like ligands, the neutral ligand L. The investigaton of the magnetic properties of complexes 1–3 demonstrates that they all display FM coupling between CoII ions but AFM interaction between Co3 or Co2 units. Further studies of azido complexes with N-containing heterocyclic and aromatic carboxylates are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three new CoII-azido coordination complexes with a semiflexible di(1H-imidazol-1-yl)methane ligand and different dicarboxylate-like ligands as the subligands have been structurally and magnetically characterized. This work shows that it is feasible to substitute the N-containing carboxylate with a neutral N-containing heterocyclic ligand and dicarboxylate in the azido system, which have generated three novel 3D CoII-azido complexes from different dicarboxylate-like ligands, the neutral ligand L. The investigaton of the magnetic properties of complexes 1-3 demonstrates that they all display FM coupling between CoII ions but AFM interaction between Co3 or Co2 units. Further studies of azido complexes with N-containing heterocyclic and aromatic carboxylates are in progress.

cln_elements.content:
Caution! Azido–metal complexes are potentially explosive; only a small amount of material should be prepared with care.

Synthesis

Single crystals of 1–3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by the method described below for 1, except H2-m-BDC for 2 and H2-p-BDC for 3 were used as ligands instead of H2-o-BDC.

[Co<sub>3</sub>(L)<sub>2</sub>(<italic toggle="yes">o</italic>-BDC)<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

1 was hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. A mixture of CoSO4·7H2O (1.5 mmol), L (0.5 mmol), H2-o-BDC (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), and CH3OH (15 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 24 h. Pink crystals were collected in ∼10% yield based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H24Co3N14O8: C, 40.70; H, 2.73; N, 22.15. Found: C, 40.96; H, 2.87; N, 22.07. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3413, 3122, 2077, 1561, 1401, 1233, 1085, 771, 719, 613 cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Caution! Azido-metal complexes are potentially explosive; only a small amount of material should be prepared with care. 

Synthesis

Single crystals of 1-3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by the method described below for 1, except H2-m-BDC for 2 and H2-p-BDC for 3 were used as ligands instead of H2-o-BDC.

[Co3(L)2(o-BDC)2(N3)2] n  (1)

 1 was hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. A mixture of CoSO4⋅7H2O (1.5 mmol), L (0.5 mmol), H2-o-BDC (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), and CH3OH (15 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 140 °C. After being maintained for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature in 24 h. Pink crystals were collected in ~10% yield based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H24Co3N14O8: C, 40.70; H, 2.73; N, 22.15. Found: C, 40.96; H, 2.87; N, 22.07. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3413, 3122, 2077, 1561, 1401, 1233, 1085, 771, 719, 613 cm-1.

Purple crystals. Yield: ∼15% based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C30H26Co3N14O9: C, 39.88; H, 2.90; N, 21.71. Found: C, 39.47; H, 2.73; N, 20.91. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3415, 3122, 2082, 1611, 1561, 1397, 1095, 717 cm–1.

[Co<sub>2</sub>(L)<sub>2</sub>(<italic toggle="yes">p</italic>-BDC)(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·2<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>MeOH (<bold>3</bold>)

Light purple crystals. Yield: ∼15% based on L. Elemental analysis (%). Anal. Calcd for C24H28Co2N14O6: C, 39.68; H, 3.88; N, 26.99. Found: C, 39.88; H, 3.72; N, 26.87. FT-IR (KBr pellets): 3414, 3134, 2066, 1617, 1555, 1400, 1234, 1083, 1027, 942, 842, 747, 615 cm–1.

Magnetic susceptibility data of 1 were collected for the crushed crystalline sample in the 2–300 K temperature range (Figure a). The value of χm T at 300 K is 10.58 cm3 K mol–1, which is consistent with that of three CoII ions with strong spin–orbit coupling. As the temperature decreases, the χm T product increases to 46.07 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, indicating FM coupling between CoII ions in 1. The susceptibility of 1 follows the Curie–Weiss law of χm = C/(T – θ) at >80 K with a Curie constant C of 10.31 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant θ of 12.58 K indicating FM coupling in 1. The C value is consistent with that expected for three six-coordinated high-spin CoII ions (C = 2.8–3.4 cm3 K mol–1 for one high-spin CoII ion).

The temperature dependence of χm T for complex 2 as a χm T versus T plot (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility for three CoII ions) in the range of 2–300 K, under an applied field of 1 kOe, is shown in Figure b. During cooling, the value of χm T continues to increase from 8.44 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K to 18.23 cm3 K mol–1 at 6 K. Below this temperature, because of the AFM interaction between Co3 units and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS), the χm T value decreases sharply to 15.56 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Fitting the data at 60–300 K with the Curie–Weiss law gives a C of 8.33 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of 13.83 K. The C value is consistent with the value of 8.44 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K. The positive value of θ indicates FM coupling between CoII ions.

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data for complex 3 were collected with an applied dc field of 1 kOe in the 2–300 K temperature range (Figure c). The χm T product at 300 K equals 3.43 cm3 K mol–1, in agreement with that expected for one isolated CoII ion with spin–orbital coupling. As the temperature decreases, the χm T product increases slightly, indicating FM interactions within CoII ions, until a maximum value of 3.78 cm3 K mol–1 is reached at 50 K. Then because of the AFM interaction between Co2 units and/or ZFS, the χm T value decreases to 0.79 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. Fitting of the χm –1–T data above 80 K using the Curie–Weiss law gives a C of 3.33 cm3 K mol–1 and a θ of 9.36 K, which support the presence of FM interactions in the Co2 unit. The abnormal value at 40 K might be attributed to the presence of traces of paramagnetic impurities.

The temperature dependence of χm T for complex 2 as a χm T versus T plot (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility for three CoII ions) in the range of 2-300 K, under an applied field of 1 kOe, is shown in Figure b. During cooling, the value of χm T continues to increase from 8.44 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K to 18.23 cm3 K mol-1 at 6 K.
